characters: ANOTHER WOMAN, PULLING OFF HER DRESS.
A HAND COUNTING MONEY IN THE BROWN ENVELOPE.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Hold on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BIKE MESSENGER stands outside Kat’s door. He busts a covert ipod dance while he waits.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Coming! INT. KAT’S FOYER Kat wipes her face and inhales, summoning deep calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bike Messenger looks up as the door swings open. Kat_is a_ changed woman. Nothing like the girl we saw on floor. You’d never know she had been crying. Or that she even knows how.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry. I wasn’t quite ready for you. Kat props the door open with her foot as she slides a pla ticket into an envelope. She scribbles a name on the envelope, seals it, and hands it to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, you said this was a rush. I can’t rush anything anywhere if you don’t give it to me. Kat looks down at the envelope, she’s still holding on to

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: It’s a plane ticket.

dialogues.speaker: BIKE MESSENGER
dialogues.text: So it is.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: For a date. (beat) For my date. To my sister’s wedding. In London. (beat) He’s never met my family.

dialogues.speaker: BIKE MESSENGER
dialogues.text: I hear that noise. Kat wills herself to surrender the envelope. BIKE MESSENGER (CONT’D) You need to let go.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Yeah. (beat) You’re going to have to help me. The Bike Messenger gently tugs the envelope out of her ha Kat smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. The Bike Messenger looks at her with genuine concern. INT. KAT’S APARTMENT Racing against time, Kat throws open a linen closet to re three neat rows of plastic bins, all perfectly labeled. K reaches into the bin marked "TRAVEL" and pulls out a pre- packed toiletry kit. Kat pulls a box marked “LONDON” out from underneath her b She opens it. Pushing aside an old private school uniform and some let she pulls out a worn London A-Z, a Ziploc marked “ADAPTER and her passport. She’s about to close the box when she sees an old photo. it, a GORGEOUS GUY kisses Kat on the cheek. He’s holding camera himself -- it’s blurred and goofy, but full of lov Kat jams it back in the box and shoves it under the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bike Messenger darts in and out of traffic, avoiding throngs of NEW YORKERS enjoying this crisp fall day. INT. KAT’S APARTMENT Kat races through her apartment, packing, cleaning, getti ready. Her place is small yet put together. It’s Crate an Barrel meets Martha. But in a good way. INT. KAT’S BATHROOM Kat, finally still, stares into the mirror as she brushes teeth. There’s a strange intensity to it, like she’s scrubbing away the last of her distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bike Messenger passes a waiting Town Car as he pulls to a stoop. He hefts his bike, runs up the stairs, and sl the envelope into the door of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tasteful flat. Stylish yet masculine. A MAN stoops to pick up the envelope. We don’t see his face, just his ordered, minimalist apartment as he zips his carry-on and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face obscured, the man steps into the purring Town Ca EXT. KAT’S APARTMENT BUILDING A TAXI DRIVER slams his trunk as Kat gets in. Kat’s apprehensive face peers out the window as they pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ridiculously long line snakes towards the X-Ray machine Latte in hand, Kat cuts right through the middle. Irate PASSENGERS scowl at her. Kat does this every day. S should be used to the looks by now. She’s not. She pointedly flashes the crowd her AIRPORT EMPLOYEE BADGE as sails through security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat enters the Virgin Atlantic customer service hub. It’s cramped as it is busy. A FEMALE EMPLOYEE approaches with question. Kat puts up her hand.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m off duty. I do not exist. Don’t even look at me. The lady backs off. As Kat hurries away, a HARRIED EMPLOY matches her step and launches in.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIED EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: I’ve got a tour group from Taipei trapped in customs, a dead poodle in Cargo parked at T9, and a lost grandmother staggering around International asking for her mommy. Oh, and there’s a guy on two who was stuck with his in-laws for a week because we couldn’t get him out of Dulles. The in-laws aren’t speaking to him anymore and, for some reason, he’s pissed. Kat’s trying not to get sucked in.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I would love to help you. Sincerely. But my sister’s getting married this weekend, I haven’t seen my family in two years, and my flight leaves in fifteen minutes. The Harried Employee looks like he’s going to lose it. Ka struggles, then caves.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You take Taipei. Tammy’s schnauzer just had puppies. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAT(cont'd) Put her on the dead dog. Park reps with wheelchairs at every john in T8. If Grandma just got off a trans-con she’s gotta go sometime. Kat starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: HARRIED EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: What about line two? Kat spins around and glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the phone, Kat is in the middle of saying way too much

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (into phone) I completely understand, sir. You just want your in-laws to see you the way you see yourself. Or at least the way you would see yourself if you didn’t feel so victimized by them. At that moment, a CLIPBOARD manager walks by. He overhear Kat’s diatribe and is incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD
dialogues.text: Hello? Calls may be monitored for quality control?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: CLIPBOARD
dialogues.text: Over -share! Kat waves him off. Then, by rote:

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (into phone) Mr. Rajagopal, we regret that you were snowed in at Dulles but snowstorms fall under a category called force majeure. Along with earthquakes, hurricanes, and floods. In short, we’re not liable. Kat checks to make sure the Clipboard has moved on. she continues, softly but very quickly. Then,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) But just this once, I’m going to refund the full price of your ticket and credit you 10,000 frequent flyer miles. Thank you for calling Virgin Atlantic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat sits in first class, absently scanning the safety car A PRETTY WOMAN across the aisle notices and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: Your first trip? Kat realizes she’s been reading the safety card. She laug and puts it back in the seat pocket. As she often does, K feels compelled to explain.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Hardly. My family moved to England when I was fourteen. My stepdad’s a professor at University College, London. (beat) I’m going back for my sister’s wedding...and the best man’s my ex. In case I chicken out, I want to know where all the exits are. Kat eyes the front door, nervously.

dialogues.speaker: PRETTY WOMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t believe in marriage. I believe in hot sex. Of course, that draws men to me like flies to shit. Kat doesn’t know what to say, but then a HOT GUY walks up aisle. Kat looks at the empty seat next to her and smiles him. He returns the smile but sits next to the Pretty Wom

dialogues.speaker: HOT GUY
dialogues.text: Hello, my sweet darling. He gives the Pretty Woman a “madly in love” kiss. The Pre Woman rolls her eyes to Kat -- what did I tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat is hiding out. She tries to calm her nerves as a MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT pours her a cup of water

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m not a knuckler. I fly all the time. In fact, I transferred from Heathrow two years ago and now I run Bags and Nags here at Kennedy, so things are going really well for me. The reason I can’t feel my legs is that any minute, my date is going to walk in that door. And I need him to look really, really good today.

dialogues.speaker: MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (not listening) I wish I couldn’t feel my legs. Kat peeks around the corner and spots the back of the mysterious MAN from the opening as he loads the overhead above Kat’s seat. Kat gasps, ducking back.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oh, no. He’s here. The Male Flight Attendant looks out at the Man, who leans against Kat’s seat as he chats with a FEMALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT. Kat’s in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you think? Does he look hot, and is it the kinda hot that’1l translate overseas?

dialogues.speaker: MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: I resent your stereotyping of a man in my profession but... He checks out the guy again. MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT (CONT’D) ...darling, he’d be hot on Mars. I’d like to unwrap him like a Harrod’s gift basket. Kat smiles, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The mystery man is NICK MERCER, 32, commanding and classy yet somehow totally genuine. He carries his ‘40s-crooner good looks like he has no idea that men just aren’t made way anymore. Nick takes two glasses of champagne from the blushing Fem Flight Attendant.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thank you, Lisa. He turns around to take his seat and finds Kat standing there, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Hi. Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Kat. Nick kisses Kat warmly on the cheek and hands her a glass champagne. Nick’s totally at ease. This may as well be a candle-lit bar.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let’s sit. Kat awkwardly negotiates her drink as they take their sea

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m glad you found it okay. The airport. The plane, I mean. Nick notices Kat’s anxiety, tries to settle her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I really am sorry I couldn’t leave earlier. I know you would have loved a few hours to settle in before the party. Kat melts a little. That’s just what she was thinking.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Work must be crazy right now. Nick gives Kat a quizzical look. There’s something going here. Though it’s not clear what. Kat fills the space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’ve gotta warn you, you know those families where everyone’s out of their minds but at the end of the day, they’re family, so you love them? (off his nod) Mine’s not like that. The Flight Attendant appears with a small tray. Kat notic the woman’s cheeks flush as she fumbles Nick’s drink. Nick smiles warmly, but deftly ends the moment. He’s like famous person who has learned to manage his adoring fans casual grace.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love my dad. But since he’s my stepdad, he’s technically not family. He’s more like a hostage. Kat tries to find her seat belt. It’s under Nick. She reaches beneath him, tentatively, then pulls back embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My seat belt, it’s.... Nick pulls out the seat belt and hands it to her. Kat buckles up, checks that it’s snug, then checks again. They sit in silence as the plane starts barreling down th runway. As they pick up speed, Nick takes Kat’s hand. She finds comfort in his touch, her need to talk abates momentarily She is safe. Kat closes her eyes as the plane levels off, then peeks o at Nick, who’s calmly staring out the window. She closes eyes again, this time for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Kat wait at the baggage claim. She looks at his tie, then down at her dress. They are the exact same colo  10.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (concerned) Please tell me you’re not wearing that tonight. Her dress is indeed the exact same color as Nick’s tie.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: It’s no big deal. Really. It just looks like a tailor cut off a yard of my dress and made your tie out of it. Nick doesn’t get it. He heaves one of Kat’s suitcases ont trolley full of matching suitcases.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t get me wrong, matching’s fine. It’s “matchy matchy” you’ve got to watch out for. (re: outfits) This is matchy-matchy. Nick, amused, tugs the last of the bags off the carousel adds it to a pile of what appears to be an entire floor m of matching luggage.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You think we look like we’re trying too hard.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Exactly. I want us to look like we fit, but not like we’re trying too hard to look like we fit. (beat) It’s welcome cocktails, not prom. With this level of matchy-matchy, we should be drinking peach schnapps under a bleacher somewhere. Nick laughs at Kat. Then fixes her with an intense stare.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’1l teach you a trick. If you look people in the eye, they’1l never even notice what you have on. Kat, overwhelmed by his charisma, is mesmerized.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What color are my shoes?  11.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (dreamily) You have feet? Nick smiles sweetly and touches her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Heathrow Express thunders towards London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick stands by the W.C., flipping through Cosmo. He can d that without looking gay. He talks to Kat through the doo

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I understand how important this is to you, but you’re a beautiful woman and you’ve got everything in the world going for you. I couldn’t care less what you have on. Kat comes out modeling a black strapless.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Don’t patronize me. They’ve clearly been at this a while.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You’re funny.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I feel like crap. And if you feel like crap, it’s way better to look hot while you’re doing it He checks her out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mission accomplished.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Really? (beat) Don’t get too attached. She bolts back to the bathroom, nearly knocking over a ZI TEENAGER who’s waiting his turn.  12.

dialogues.speaker: ZITTY TEENAGER
dialogues.text: I liked the red one better.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’1l let her know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat, alone in the W.C., meticulously rearranges a layer o paper towel on the floor so she can step out of her shoes She expertly slides off the first dress while simultaneou pulling another one on -- not an inch of skin shows. She struggles as the train rocks back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (through the door) I bet you’re doing that girl thing, where you get undressed without showing any skin. Kat looks around suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: No, I’m not. How’d he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat emerges from the bathroom wearing the new dress. Nick checks it out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Mmm.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Mmm, nice dress? Or mmm-- (British accent) Gorgeous, I was insane to let you go!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Both. Kat looks to the Zitty Teenager for his opinion.

dialogues.speaker: ZITTY TEENAGER
dialogues.text: I’d do you. (to Nick) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ZITTY TEENAGER(cont 'd) I mean, if it was all right with you. Kat gives the passenger an appreciative smile, then flies back into the bathroom. Nick, amused by her antics, steps closer to the door.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You know, they say you can tell everything you need to know about a person from the way they act when they’re naked.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (popping her head out) I don’t do naked. My sister? She does naked. Kat ducks back into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat pulls her dress over her head.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER WOMAN, PULLING OFF HER DRESS.
dialogues.text: INT. AMY’S BATHROOM The woman is Kat’s sister, AMY ELLIS, 28. She graces a ba mat in all her infinite nakedness. Totally nude, she gent places her veil on her head and begins the ablutions of a Greek goddess. A dot of bath oil, a pure white towel, one squirt self-tanner, one squirt lotion. Finally, she pulls out a bottle of olive oil, pours two d into her hands and rubs them together. Then she stares in the mirror, regarding herself with a l so blank it could be anything from admiration to revulsio Just then, a KNOCK. The groom, EDWARD FLETCHER-WOOTEN, 31, enters, wearing a robe. He flashes Amy as he does a silly dance then smothe her inside his robe. Amy giggles and tries to break free.  14. At first she’s laughing, but then she turns on a dime and shoves him off more forcefully than she meant to. She kisses him on the lips, trying to cover, and shoos hi out the door. INT. BUNNY’S DRESSING ROOM he mother of the bride, BUNNY ELLIS, 60, drops her robe o he floor. She is about to put on a bra when she catches h eflection in a full-length mirror on the door. std She is momentarily surprised by what she sees. She turns faces her image. This is not the woman she is in her head This is an old woman with uncooperative skin. With one sw movement, she slams the door. INT. ELLIS HOUSE - ST. JOHN’S WOOD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The father of the bride, VICTOR ELLIS, 65, wearing only a pair of socks, walks downstairs. He's completely comforta in his nakedness and trots around as if he's fully clothe He sings to himself. The words of the song are incomprehensible but he sings with an unrestrained Sinatr sass. Victor enters the kitchen, opens the fridge and starts scrounging. Inside the fridge door, Victor bends over and his bare butt sticks out. As he closes the fridge door, w cut to... A SHOWER DOOR SLIDING OPEN. INT. JEFFREY’S FLAT Inside, the best man, JEFFREY JOHNSON, 31, the guy from t snapshot under Kat’s bed, glistens with a post-shower flu Jeffrey towels off with a miniscule washcloth. Stepping out of the bathroom, Jeffrey notices an 18-year- NYMPHETTE watching him through her kitchen window. He crosses to the window but instead of closing the blinds, opens them wider and jumps up onto a pull-up bar. The Nymphette blushes and looks away. As he starts pumpin and his manhood rises dangerously close to frame, we...

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Upscale cars deliver upscale people to this stately hotel Central London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick pays the BELLHOP, who trolleys away their bags. He turns to find Kat. She’s wearing the red dress. The Zitty Teenager was right. It’s really hot. Kat starts doing a yoga breath of fire, trying to relax. Nick takes Kat’s hand and pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You okay, hon? Kat nods, clearly not okay. Nick smooths a piece of hair behind her ear. There is a practiced intimacy to the way touches her and Kat is almost settled by it.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I can do this. Nick moves towards Kat as if he’s going to kiss her, but he whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You’re never going to be sure of anything, but we still have to go inside. Just then, Kat’s mother appears.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: (singing) “Baby love, my baby love.” A few BRITS dart looks at this very American display.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Please, Mom. This is not the time to be yourself. Bunny folds Kat and Nick into a drunken embrace. Bunny gi Nick the once-over.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: (to Nick) And who might this be?  16. Kat’s mortified but Nick quickly saves her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m the new guy. (kissing Bunny) It’s great to meet you. Bunny throws Kat an unsubtle, “I’m impressed” look and le them into the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny, Kat and Nick emerge into a sea of Burberry, floppy hair, and unspoken judgments. Bunny turns to Nick and Kat all business.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: This is a marathon, not a sprint. After welcome cocktails, you’ve got the hen party. Tomorrow, there’s a picnic and the rehearsal dinner and since you’ve conveniently left no margin for jet lag-- (squeezing Kat’s cheek) I need you to hydrate, baby. Nick and Kat are stunned. Bunny hops away as Victor approaches. Kat throws her arms around her stepfather.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Hi, kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Meet Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Sir. They shake hands. Just then, Kat’s sister, Amy, dressed t the nines, strikes a pose in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’m getting MARRIED! As Kat and Amy squeal loudly and hug, Victor leans into N

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: I find a good, strong drink helps.  17. Nick smiles, looks at Victor’s glass.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Can I get you a refill, sir? Victor hands Nick the glass.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (sniffing the glass) I’m guessing MacCallum, 18 years. (beat) Neat, with a water-back.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Is there any other way to take it? Nick heads toward the bar and Victor turns to Kat. VICTOR (CONT’D) Where’d you find this guy? Kat smiles, appreciatively.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: The Yellow Pages. Victor laughs. Across the room, Bunny has found a microphone. She taps a knife on the side of a glass to ge everyone’s attention.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Welcome, friends and family! Then she taps the mic, which squeals. ON KAT, panic stricken.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Sweet Jesus, who gave that woman an amp? ON BUNNY, drunk with happiness.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Victor and I would especially like to thank our out-of-town guests for coming to celebrate with us as we welcome Edward and the Fletcher- Wootens into our family. THE CAMERA ID’s LYDIA and GEORGE FLETCHER-WOOTEN, 60’s. George shifts uncomfortably. Lydia waves as though addressing a room full of her subjects.  18. ON JEFFREY, searching the crowd for someone. His eyes lan on Kat. She doesn’t see him. He stares at her meaningfull BUNNY (CONT’D) It’s funny. We always thought we’d marry off Kat first. We came close once, but that crashed and burned. Nervous laughter from the crowd. Kat smiles through the pain. Jeffrey winces sympathetically. His mind working, h spots a piano nearby. BUNNY (CONT’D) Still, we had reason to hope. She was always one of the more “active” girls at the American school, and that’s saying a lot. Suddenly, a loud, lovely arpeggio from the piano. Bunny looks over, surprised. Then she smiles. ANGLE ON JEFFREY, sitting at the piano, playing. BUNNY (CONT’D) Okay, okay. I get the hint! Anyway, imagine our surprise when Ed moved in next door and fell in love with...the girl next door. Our Amy. Lucky for us, he had no idea it was an unforgiveable cliché. (raising her glass) A toast to the bride and groom to be. Congratulations, babies! Everyone claps as Jeffrey plays a final flourish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat is sneaking towards the ladies room when Jeffrey come out of the men’s room. Their eyes meet. Both stop dead. Neither can find words or even a smile. Kat pretends that seeing him isn’t a gut-punch, forces a silly grin.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Thanks for, you know, with the piano.... It was really.... Hm. (beat) I have to pee. Kat slithers past Jeffrey into the w.c.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat wills her breath back. She turns on the water as if s were washing her hands. Then she confronts herself in the mirror and applies a coat of lipstick like she’s putting suit of armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeffrey, a dashing Brit, is not a man who likes to wait, wait he has. Kat emerges from the W.C. as if she hadn’t s him before.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Why, Jeffrey. Hello.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Hello, Katmandu. As Jeffrey kisses her on the cheek, Kat’s eyes close and takes in his smell. It’s like coming home. She doesn’t wa it to, but something inside her stirs. JEFFREY (CONT’D) You look well, Gorgeous. All he has to do is look her in the eyes and her big plan fly out the window. Kat blushes. JEFFREY (CONT’D) Seeing you again....

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Yeah? Just then, TJ, 30, Kat’s cousin, appears, wrapping Kat in hug. TJ’s deb-of-the-year perkiness is undercut by her Longshoreman’s tongue.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: Kat Ellis! We live two hundred miles away from each other but I have to fly all the way to London to see you. You haven’t visited me once in D.C. Where the hell have you been? I have gynecologists that call more often.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: You have more than one gynecologist?  20.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: Sure. You’ve got to play them against each other. Otherwise they think you’re easy. TJ turns on Jeffrey like she just realized he was there. TJ (CONT’D) Hey, asshole, since you dumped my cousin brutally and without cause, you won’t mind if I steal her away? I have all kinds of interesting things to tell her. TJ darts Jeffrey a dirty look and drags Kat away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arms locked, Kat and TJ rejoin the party.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: You didn’t have to do that

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: I wasn’t saving you from him. I was saving you from yourself. You’re too fucking nice.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Don’t worry. I’m so over him. (beat) By the way, do you know if he’s seeing anyone? They spot Nick talking to Bunny, surrounded by OCTOGENARI He doesn’t look the least bit lost. In fact, he’s charmin the Dockers off them.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: Why waste ten more seconds on the slimy limey when Mr. Tie-Me-Up-Tie-Me- Down is waiting for you at the bar? ANGLE ON NICK, listening patiently as Bunny pours her hea out.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: After Kat’s father died and I married Victor, I was so desperate for my little girl to love him. It never occurred to me that she might love him more.  21. ANGLE ON KAT AND TJ, still staring at Nick.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: What’s he do anyway?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Therapist. Just then, Nick looks up and gives Kat an intimate, “get here” look. TJ sighs audibly.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: I think I just came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick stands with Kat at the bar. The BARTENDER hands Kat drink.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Can I have that? Kat looks over and sees Amy. She puts her drink on the ba but Amy can’t quite reach it from her stool. Amy makes an exaggerated reaching gesture and whimpers. Nick takes note as Kat slides the drink closer. Amy sips through the straw without picking it up.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You know what I love about all this?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: There’s finally a reason for the whole world to revolve around you?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Exactly! Today’s my day. Tomorrow will be my day. And the day after that? My day. As Amy gloats, Ed dances over. He’s a refreshingly unaffected upper-class Brit.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: How’s the future Mrs.? Amy kisses him on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Perfect. All ginny.  22.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Except it’s Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (ignoring Kat) But I’m not taking your name, buster. I’m a feminist! (shaking her drink) I need icey! Mr. husband-man, get me more icey!

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: All right, then kiss me. (she kisses him) God, I’m a lucky sod. Ed lifts Amy off the stool and spins her around. He does awkward dance move and steps on her toe.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: See what happens when you put off dance lessons til two days before the wedding? Ed looks to Nick for support.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Who’s ever heard of dance lessons for a wedding, honestly?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Um, just about everyone.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: You are taking the piss? Ed looks to Kat, who shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We’1ll go with you guys tomorrow. I suck too. It’1ll be fun. Amy kisses Nick’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don’t even know you, hunky-dunky, and I love you already. Kat throws Amy a dark look.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: (to no one) Dance lessons. Right.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Escaping, Nick steps outside and bumps into Jeffrey, who teeters on the railing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. Jeffrey looks upset. Nick tries to break the ice.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: A wedding is a sacrament...a joyous celebration of love and commitment. In Utopia. In the real world... it’s an excuse to drink excessively and say things you shouldn’t say.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Ah, a philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Shrink, actually.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Crikey.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Nothing, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, tell me.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: You Yanks and your therapy. It’s great. (beat) It’s all a bit too touchy-feely for me. A beat as Jeffrey watches the party. He sees Kat and Amy the bar and slowly turns to Nick. With difficulty, he beg to unburden himself to his new therapist  24.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: It’s just, there’s this girl I care for -- God, I suppose I could even say I love her -- and the bugger is, of course, she’s here with someone else. Bollocks! Nick hides his surprise as Jeffrey raises his glass ina silent toast to his misery. Nick is just clinking glasses with him when Kat appears and slips her arm in his.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Here you are. Jeffrey is horrified. Stares at Nick, aghast

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Hey, Kat.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Hey, yourself. (to Nick) I see you’ve met my ex. They all stand there, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did I interrupt something? Jeffrey looks desperately at Nick. Nick hesitates, then covers.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I was just telling Jeffrey how we met. Kat gives Nick a confused look. Nick smiles warmly--

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Knicks game? We both wanted the last hot dog?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. (pointedly, to Jeffrey) So we split it. You know, as in “share.” People do that.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: You hate sports. Kat squeezes Nick’s arm, adoringly.  25.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Not when Nick explains them. Jeffrey’s desperate to get out of there.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: (to Nick) Right. I should be going. Good to meet you. Perhaps I’1l see you at the stag party. My place. (to Kat) You know the address. Kat watches him rejoin the party.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Well, he looks miserable. What were you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Love. Kat and Nick walk back into the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk arm and arm. After the confrontation with Jeffr Kat’s excitement is almost manic.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Jeffrey knows love like he knows macrameé.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: He was pretty drunk, but I think he’s still crazy about you.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Of course he is. I’m here with my new man. (beat) I love it! Your magic’s already working. Let the suffering begin. Nick stops Kat and faces her. He is quiet but intense.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The only one suffering here is you. You need to stop worrying about everyone else. You think you can do that?  26. Kat takes a deep, calming breath.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: No. She turns and surveys the room, trying to calm down. But then slowly her face begins to tense.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What did he say exactly? I mean you don’t think he wants me back?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What does your gut say?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You’re too good for him. EXT. ST. JOHN’S WOOD - LATER Nick drives slowly down St. John’s Wood’s tree-lined main street. Nick looks out the window as they pass a corner market, a flower shop, pubs, restaurants. EXT. ELLIS HOUSE - ST. JOHN’S WOOD A charming period house in a row of identical houses. You never know where the Americans lived but for a conspicuou boat trailer parked in the driveway. Victor and Bunny try to help Nick unload Kat’s many bags the taxi. He won’t let them. As Nick lugs the bags up the driveway, he reads the name, “JACK SHIP,” off the back of dilapidated cabin cruiser

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick struggles with Kat’s many bags as Kat’s parents esco them upstairs. Kat stops by her bedroom door, doesn’t go

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Well, here we are. They stand there, awkwardly sandwiched into the small spa  27.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (to Bunny and Victor) Thanks again for having me.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly. It’s wonderful to finally meet you. Although, technically, I had no idea you existed because when my daughter turned twelve, she stopped talking to me, except when she needed money. So let me rephrase that. It was nice to discover you existed and then finally meet you all at once. I love surprises.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Okay, Bun. That’s enough. Kat gives them a look, but doesn’t open her bedroom door.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Where’s Nick sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Why, with you.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (not listening) My mother has a rule about men and women sleeping in the same room without a ring in the picture. She thinks it’s-- Kat puts her fingers up to do air quotes, then suddenly realizes what her mother just said.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: (twinkling at Nick) I’m not as square as my daughter thinks. As Kat’s parents walk away, Bunny flirtatiously sidles up Victor and pulls him into their bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: She must have drowned her rules in the Chardonnay. With that, Kat closes the door.  28. INT. KAT’S ROOM The door CLICKS shut and the happy couple separates instantly. Kat to one side of the room, Nick to the other Kat’s childhood bedroom has an aggressively floral decor.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Sorry about the creepy room. I went through a painfully earnest Laura-Ashley phase. Kat takes a brown envelope out of her purse, opens it, an removes A STACK OF HUNDREDS. She hands the pile of money to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Count it. Six thousand even. Nick doesn’t look at the money, just tucks it into his ba

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I trust you. Kat almost lets it go, but then...

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: No, count it, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m compulsive and weird? Nick humors her. Pulls out the stack of bills and counts

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Six thousand, right?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: On the nose. (beat) I tell you what, because you’re so cute, I’1ll take care of our incidentals.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: How does it feel to get that much money just for being you?  29.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (wryly) ; Great, with the occasional stabs of shame. Now, listen, this covers the weekend, but as we discussed, if you want to be intimate, we talk money before anything happens.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: That won’t be an issue, believe me. I find the idea of sex for money morally repugnant. (realizing) No offense.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s okay. Hell, I’ve never paid for it. But please don’t feel like you have to explain yourself to me. Kat walks over to an old dollhouse. Its rooms have been gutted, their mini furnishings replaced with a teenager’s cassette-tape collection. Kat pulls out Guns and Roses’ “Appetite for Destruction” opens it. There’s no tape inside, just some nicotine patches. Nick watches as she opens one up and slaps it on

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You quitting?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m desperate to start but I don’t have an addictive personality. Except for approval. That, I can’t get enough of. Nick notices an ‘80s poster of two guys with guitars, all hair and laser light shows.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Graham Russell and Russell Hitchcock. Nick thinks about those names for a second, then his face twists.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Air Supply?  30. Embarrassed, Kat hastily rips down the poster and stuffs in the closet.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: My parents had a German exchange student a few years back.... He must have left it here. Nick hides a smile as Kat ducks into the bathroom. INT. KAT’S BATHROOM Kat has left the door open a crack as she gets ready for shower. Unbeknownst to her, Nick watches from the bed, enjoying the ritual.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (quietly) Everyone knows their greatest hits but some of their lesser-known ballads are surprisingly poignant Inexplicably, Kat stands on her tiptoes as she looks into mirror. It’s a little thing, maybe the tiles are cold, bu it gives her an innocence that makes Nick smile.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s cute.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What is?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You stand on your tiptoes.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I do? Kat looks down, she never noticed before.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Is it an old habit from ballet class or a childhood spent walking on eggshells? She throws him a glance, impressed with the sharpness of mind.  31.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I never took ballet. She smiles and kicks the door closed with her foot. INT. KAT’S ROOM - LATER Nick hangs up his tux. It’s definitely not a rental. Kat comes out of the bathroom, drying her hair with a towel.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Have you ever done anything like this before?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: A weekend?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: A wedding. Nick thinks about that. Kat wonders what’s taking him so long.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No. Though strangely, I’ve done quite a few funerals. Kat makes a face.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not the way you’re thinking. The women wanted me there for support You can understand that.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I think that’s disgusting. Kat immediately backpedals.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not you. You’re not disgusting. You’re lovely. Just the idea that they’d bring an escort. I mean, a stranger who, um, didn’t...who never.... I mean, someone’s dead.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That’s right. Imagine facing it alone. Kat blanches.  32.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Sorry. I’m a little nervous. I never thought something like this would happen to me.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: This happened to you?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Well, happen, in the sense that I picked up the phone, tracked you down, flew you here and gave you six grand out of my 401K. Nick laughs at her. Kat pulls something out of her purse.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something? Nick sees what she’s unfolding. It’s a crinkled New Yorke article. The artsy photo shows the FACE OF A MAN, blurred against a neon cityscape. The title: “Discretion Assured: Diary of a Male Escort.”

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: How did you know that was me?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I have a friend at the magazine.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (sharply) Your “friend” guaranteed my anonymity.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: If it makes you feel any better, to get your number, I had to cough up two round-trip tickets to Amsterdam and a case of mini-Baileys. Nick shakes his head at her and pulls off his shirt. Kat instinctively looks away.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You can look. It’s part of the package. Kat can’t tell if he’s joking. She sneaks a look as Nick disappears into the shower. Wow. Kat looks down at the papers in her hand. She moves towards the bathroom but at the last minute, shies away.  33.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you grab my shampoo?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Shampoo, got it! Kat grabs the shampoo and rushes into the bathroom. INT. KAT’S BATHROOM Without looking in the shower, Kat hands him the shampoo hurries out, way too quickly. Nick peeks out of the showe curtain. She’s gone. He shakes his head and closes the curtain. Suddenly, Kat reappears. She stands by the door.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: The part where you were a sexual surrogate and then started to, um, freelance. Is that really how it happened? Kat pretends to straighten things up as she moves closer the shower.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: The real story is that my mother was a hippie. And a stripper. She was insanely inappropriate with me. She used to wash her lingerie in my bathwater. While I was still in the bath.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oh, no.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah. As an adult, I needed to find some way to experience intimacy and sex, but with rules that couldn’t be violated. Kat’s totally engrossed now. She closes the toilet lid an sits down.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Wow. Nick pokes his head out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yeah.  34. Nick sees that Kat’s heartbroken for him, feels bad.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m just screwing with you. Kat throws a towel at him.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: You shit!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I have a different story for every woman who asks. I look at her and figure out what she needs to hear to feel okay about being with me.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: And you thought I’d respond to the hippie stripper with no boundaries?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Admit it. You were disturbed, but ultimately moved. Kat gives him a dirty look, then examines the article aga

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: This part here. You say, and I quote. “Each woman has the exact love life she wants.” (beat) That seems like a pretty broad generalization. Nick steps out of the shower. Kat, her eyes at the level his manhood, covers her subtle jaw-drop. Nick wraps a tow around his waist as Kat tries to pull it together. She lo down at the article, tapping it indignantly--

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...what was I...oh, yeah. Do you honestly think that I want to be single and miserable? That I want to be obsessed with some asshole who led me on for years then -- out of the blue -- shattered my heart.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: First of all, it’s never out of the blue. And second of all-- Nick levels his gaze at her.  35.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: When you’re ready to let go, to be unsingle and unmiserable, you will. Until then.... Nick shrugs and walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Kat walk downstairs, ready for a night out. Kat’ wearing an over-the-top sexy golf outfit -- pleated mini skirt, tight white oxford, plaid vest. On the bottom step Kat stops short.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (quietly) Is it always women? Nick looks at her like she’s crazy.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Are you asking me if I’m gay for pay?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I guess so.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What do you think? Nick confronts her. She takes him in.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor reads a book as Bunny scratches hieroglyphics ona white board featuring an elaborate chart of information. and Nick enter, see the chart.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (to Nick) Mom’s refining her strategy for D- Day.  36.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: I’m sure General Eisenhower never had to master the finer points of the seating chart and centerpieces. (pointing proudly) Oh, and tomorrow afternoon you are carpooling to the country with the Fletcher-Wootens.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Sir, yes, sir! She turns on her heel like a soldier, walks to Victor, an holds out her hand,

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Make sure you show Nick Regents Park. (winking) It’s romantic at night. Victor doesn’t look up, just pulls the car keys out of hi pocket and tosses them past Kat to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Better him on the wrong side of the road than you behind the wheel. Kat huffs grumpily and they head out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat and Nick walk toward the car.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: So, um. What about testing? Nick opens Kat’s door for her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: There’s a guy on 81st and Madison. You get your results in 24 hours. (beat ) Do you make your lovers get tested before you sleep with them?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: My sixth-grade science project was entitled, “Love Hurts: The Heartbreak of Human Papillomavirus.” Trust me, I’m careful.  49 37. Kat gets in the car and Nick shuts her door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick drives while Kat navigates. They crawl down a small street, which bustles with activity. PATRONS of London’s many pubs spill out onto the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I love that you’re asking questions, but do you really want to get into all of this?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: This is awkward for me. (beat) Talking about it makes me feel better. Nick looks over at Kat, who gets quiet. She picks at noth on her skirt. The TICK TICK TICK of the indicator fills t silence as Nick changes lanes.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hey. Kat looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t stop asking questions, okay?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Okay. Kat smiles, but stays quiet. Then--

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you pay taxes? 49

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick holds the door open for Kat as she gets out.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) I swear. I don’t have a signature move.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. You're like the Yoda of escorts. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KAT(cont 'd) Getting you on the phone was harder than getting into college. Nick turns off the car, gets out, walks around, and opens door for Kat. She gets out and stands by the door

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don’t have gimmicks or play games. It’s way more... Nick rubs two fingers together, he can’t think of the wor

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Subtle?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I disappear. It’s not about me. It’s about you. Nick is standing very, very close to Kat now. She didn’t even see him move but there he is.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s hard to explain.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Show me. Nick shakes his head. KAT (CONT’D) Come on.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’ve got this bad taste in my mouth. What is it? I think it’s the words: “morally repugnant.” Kat tugs urgently on his waist.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Show me. Nick doesn’t say anything for a moment. Then he pushes he up against the car. It’s a gentle movement, but firm. Kat breathes in sharply from the power of it.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. Kat’s hesitant. She looks around the empty parking lot bu Nick takes her cheek and guides her eyes to his.  39.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. She does. Nick leans in close and begins whispering into ear with a hypnotic intensity.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not going to kiss you. You can relax. You're safe. Nick takes Kat’s head in his hands and moves his lips acr the contours of her face. It’s incredibly intimate. His mouth hovers over hers but their lips don’t touch. They breathe each other in.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m not going to kiss you. Trust me. All you have to do is listen to my voice. Kat’s body starts to relax. Slowly, she slumps back again the car.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s going to be so sorry he let you go. He moves his lips across her eyelids.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’11 look at you with your sexy dress and your perfect date but it won’t matter because it’s not about him. It’s about you. As Nick slowly talks, he moves his lips across Kat’s forehead, then her cheek, then her nose:

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want you to let go of the hurt. ...the insecurity...the past. When you do, he’1ll see you the way I see you, and, in that moment, he’1l finally understand what he lost. Nick tips Kat’s chin towards him. She opens her eyes. Nic is suddenly serious.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But by then, the amazing thing is...you won’t care.  40. Kat shudders, and gradually comes to. Her eyes are lazy, feels off balance.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Holy crap. You’re worth every penny. Nick gives her a half smile.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You better get going. Kat is turned on and can’t seem to move.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Okay, Yoda. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Go. Nick turns Kat around and points her toward the bar next door. Wearing an almost dopey look of pleasure, she adjus her underwear, and stumbles towards the bar. A sly smile creeps across her lips as we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat passes out the shots to a pack of WOMEN all wearing hybrid golf-slut outfits: ass-tight polo shirts and plaid Capri pants abound. It’s “Society Girls Gone Wild.”

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Yo, ladies! Listen up! The bride has made the foolhardy and perhaps fatal request, that we play Pub Golf tonight. (holding up a shot) Behold hole one. There’s a two- stroke penalty for failure to finish a hole and a three-stroke penalty for barfing. Yell “Fore!” before you barf and it’s only two strokes. The girls are scared shitless.  41.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We’ve got eight more holes waiting at eight more bars, so in the name of all things sacred, pace yourselves! (raising her shot) To Amy! Amy loves the attention.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: To me! Cheering, the girls blow out their shots and do their bes down them in one go. Just then, Nick walks in. All eyes are drawn to him. The WORLD SLOWS as he beelines for Kat. He hands Kat her purse.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I thought you might need this. Kat gives Nick a shy smile.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Silly me, where was my head? Kat can’t help noticing that the group of girls has subtl clustered around Nick.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: Stay. Have a fiery drink with us.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don’t know.... A SMITTEN GIRL puts a drink in Nick’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: SMITTEN GIRL
dialogues.text: Stay. Nick looks to Kat, she smiles. Amy furrows her brow theatrically. Unfortunately, no one sees her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick is surrounded by women and completely at ease. Amy’s drunk and pouty. TJ stands between Kat and Amy. Oblivious to the brewing tension, she’s eating beer nuts and starin Nick.  42.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: It’s like the director’s cut of “9 1/2 Weeks.” She pops a nut in her mouth. TJ (CONT’D) The thing about Nick is, you’re either looking at him, or you’re pretending not to. (beat) Me? I’m looking. (to Amy) Can you believe Kat gets to sleep with this guy? Amy sneers. TJ turns back to Kat TJ (CONT’D) Honestly, you should send God a bottle of wine or a muffin basket TJ clinks glasses with Kat. Kat appreciates the attention Amy appreciates it less. She suddenly wails.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Why is he still here?! This snaps Kat out of her reverie. She scurries into prob solving mode.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oh, sorry. You’re right. Girls only. Kat turns and throws Nick a look. Nick, ever sensitive to nuances, easily catches the hint and puts on his coat to

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Ladies, thank you for granting me this rare glimpse into a timeless female ritual. (raising his glass) To the husbands who won you, the losers who lost you, and to the lucky bastards who have yet to meet you. They all clink glasses. Kat beams, until...

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: (sour) And to the cock in the hen house.  43. Nick kisses Kat on the cheek and smoothly departs. They a watch him walk out. TJ is still watching the door, as if Nick’s essence has lingered.

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: I can’t believe you met him first It’s so depressing. Somebody buy my wooha a drink. Kat raises her drink to TJ’s nether region.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: To TJ’s lady business. And to Amy!

dialogues.speaker: GUYS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: To Ed! INT. JEFFREY’S FLAT - SAME A DOZEN MEN down their shots. Jeffrey immediately refills their glasses with tequila. Alcohol and alpha abound. Nic walks in the front door. He takes off his suit coat and tries not to feel like the chaperone at a frat party. Over by the bar, Jeffrey stands with Ed, eyeing Nick.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: What’s his problem?

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: There’s something about him that’s just a bit odd.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Other than, he’s shagging your ex- girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: No, that’s not it. Jeffrey pours Ed another drink. JEFFREY (CONT’D) You are a tosser. Jeffrey’s suddenly emotional.  44.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Remember when we went hiking in the lake district and Amy was wearing that little bikini thing.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: It was before you started going out. We had lunch at that inn on the lake.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Right. The Rat and Parrot.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: And Kat was fully clothed.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: But, somehow, it was Kat’s arse that was stung by nettles. And you rubbed it with a dandelion leaf.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: That’s when I realized I wanted to be a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up. You’re an optician.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Lasik surgeon, actually. Jeffrey takes a thoughtful sip of beer.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I didn’t deserve her back then.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: And you do now? Jeffrey looks genuinely pained, then something dawns on h

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Maybe I hate women. Nick appears.  45.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: All women or just the two-legged ones who steal your money, screw your friends, and vacuum during the World Cup? Jeffrey laughs. He has no idea Nick is making fun of him.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Jeff was just reminiscing about your girlfriend’s backside. Ed crosses away and Jeffrey glances nervously at Nick.

dialogues.speaker: JEFFREY
dialogues.text: Look, the thing is. About that love-of-my-life nonsense. I would appreciate it if you didn’t say anything to Kat. It was silly. It’s all rather complicated. Nick is about to respond when the music CRESCENDOS and a STRIPPER strides in from the back room. Spotting Ed, Jeff clothes-lines him and drags him off into a chorus of GUY- HOWLS and CHEERS. INT. WOODY’S WATERING HOLE - LATER The bachelorette-party girls CHEER as they down drink num seven at bar number seven, an Australian outback-themed p Things have gone way downhill -- or uphill -- depending o how you look at it. Kat sits at the bar. In the background, Amy dances drunke with TJ. WOODY, the dorky, sexy Australian bartender, appears behind the bar with a drink for Kat.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: This one’s on the house. Kat grabs his sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m worried. Amy’s not good at drinking. She gets sooo drunk sooo fast. Does free alcohol get you less drunk or more drunker? (to herself) Is it ‘drunker’ or ‘drunker-er’?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Just drunk enough.  46. Woody dumps out the free drink and exchanges it with a bo of water. WOODY (CONT’D) If you switch now, you might be able to stand up for the ceremony. Kat looks at him for the first time and realizes she know him.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Woody? Woody just smiles.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: “Not yet...”

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: “,.,but it’s getting there. “ Kat clumsily lunges across the bar to hug him, knocking o a bottle of beer, which Woody deftly catches.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought you were living in San Francisco. Or was it Nepal?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Close. Sydney. Turns out, I missed the rain. They take each other in. Her smile is bleary.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You look so much better. Woody’s trying not to feel shy around Kat.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this what you’re doing? Bartending? (beat) Not that it’s not great. It’s just, you used to have dreams and plans. Woody proudly points to Kat’s cocktail napkin. It says WOODY’S WATERING HOLE.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoa! Good for you!  47. Woody’s weighing something. He decides to say it.

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: I always wondered what happened with us.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (taken aback) I haven’t thought about that in years. Just then, Amy comes up behind Kat.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Did Kat tell you she dumped you because of your funky breath?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Did Amy tell you she keeps her Homecoming tiara by the bed? To Kat’s annoyance, Amy laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She’s drunk. -er than me. But I didn’t really dump you, did I?

dialogues.speaker: WOODY
dialogues.text: Hard. Woody smiles, sweetly. WOODY (CONT’D) Which was understandable -- you were one of the hottest girls at the American School, but I sort of thought you‘d be nicer...at least tell me why...’cause we were friends first. Kat’s on the spot. Embarrassed. Amy’s drunk-dancing and mumbling to herself.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: And we know Kat was the hottest ex- pat in school because she was voted Best Eyes, Brightest Smile, and Most Likely to Age Well. No, wait. That was me. Never mind. Kat can’t take it.  48.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Christ, Amy.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Oh, shut up and be happy. It’s always this or that. You’re never happy, you frowny-faced Grumplestilskin.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Drunk isn’t the same thing as happy, Amy. They both know they’re serious but Amy pouts and throws h arms around Kat.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: You’re my half sister, but I whole love you. Kat’s furious but she forces a smile.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Why don’t you get my half sister her seventh hole?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Bacardi 151. Woody disappears just as Amy teeters and catches herself the bar.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Are you okay? Amy’s drunkenness turns. Tears well up in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I don’t think I can go through with this.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Pub Golf?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: The wedding. (loud whisper) I am so, so bad! I don’t think I should be allowed to get married. Kat is blindsided.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  49. Then, as quickly as she went into the darkness, Amy pops She yells over to TJ.

dialogues.speaker: AMY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: TJ! Virginia Slim! TJ comes dancing up, hands Amy a cigarette and a lighter. crowd watches as Amy puts the cigarette in her lips, pour the shot into TJ’s open mouth and lights it on fire with lighter. Then she leans over and LIGHTS HER CIGARETTE ON FLAMES COMING OUT OF TJ’S MOUTH. The bar erupts in CHEERS but Kat is left worried, trouble Amy’s confession. A beat, then she downs her shot. EXT. ED’S HOUSE - LATER The cheers ECHO in the night as Nick helps Ed walk toward his house. Ed navigates the pavement like it’s made of water. They reach the front door

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (propping Ed up) You’re okay. You got it. Ed wobbles, then stands up by himself. Nick unlocks the door.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: Just because some slag’s been paid for, doesn’t mean you've got to...you know.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: It’s been my experience that the people who hire a prostitute, need a prostitute. (beat) You did the right thing. Ed blinks at Nick.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: I think I love you, mate. (beat) How do you know so much about so much?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I’m a hooker.  50. Ed bursts out laughing, pats him on the back, and walks i his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bachelorette girls ride home in “The Pub Prowler.” It a senior citizen med-van that’s been pimped out with a fu bar and an all-shag-all-the-time interior. The girls are drunk and rowdy. Kat climbs up behind the DRIVER and taps her on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Can you pull over at the next seven

dialogues.speaker: ATMS
dialogues.text: The Driver gives Kat a dubious look, then pulls up to a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Kat jumps out of The Pub Prowler and clumsily slots her card into the machine. --Kat checks her lipstick in the mirrored security camera a different ATM machine then flips through a stack of cre cards. She pulls out a different card and slips it in. --ECU on screen: MAXIMUM WITHDRAWAL £200. Kat’s at anothe ATM. In the Prowler, a couple of girls heckle passers-by Kat rifles through her cards, desperate for some un-maxed plastic. --The Prowler drops off a couple more girls. Kat walks ba from an ATM and gets in. EXT. TJ’S HOTEL - NIGHT Kat and Amy wave at TJ as she trips out of the Prowler an stumbles towards her hotel. TJ waves back with a bright happy smile--

dialogues.speaker: TJ
dialogues.text: That was awesome! How much do we rock? (beat) Fore!  51. She whips around and throws up in a topiary. In the Prowl Amy and Kat wince. TJ whips back up.

dialogues.speaker: I WIN
dialogues.text: She waves at Kat and Amy and trots past the STOIC DOORMAN who holds the door open for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat and Amy stand in the driveway. They watch as the Prow pulls away. Amy is about to head next door, when she turn to Kat.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: It was a great party. Thank you. Amy reaches out to hug Kat. Kat wasn’t expecting the hug it’s awkward. Amy senses it and pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Do you want to come in for a minute? We could talk about--

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: When I freaked out at the pub? (she hiccups) That was nothing, just nerves. Don’t worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: But Ido. Iwill. You’re my sister. With a post-Bacardi 151 suddenness, Amy’s face contorts w shame. She recoils, an angry tear running down her face.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: God, Kat! Please. Don’t be nice to me. I can take anything right now but you being nice to me.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (wildly confused) What? Why? What do you mean? Amy is suddenly in terrible distress.

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I should get going.  52.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Are you sure you’re okay?

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: I’m fine. I promise. Kat wants to say more but Amy is already walking away. Ka turns towards the house and just catches the light shutti off in her upstairs room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat shuts the front door. She leans against it for a mome to get her balance, clear her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat sits at the kitchen table, a glass of water in front her. She downs three aspirin and stares into the darkness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat starts up the stairs. The first step CREAKS loudly. Remembering countless school-age sneak-ins, Kat flattens foot against the back of each step and soundlessly walks the stairs. INT. KAT’S ROOM - ELLIS HOUSE Nick is asleep in Kat’s bed, bare-chested under a single sheet. The CAMERA FINDS Kat standing with her back to the door staring at Nick. Nick stirs, opens his eyes, and rises on one arm.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You okay? Kat walks to him, takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (whispering) Shhhh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat leads Nick down the driveway towards the BOAT TRAILER  53. On it, the twenty-six-foot CABIN CRUISER with peeling pai Kat unbuttons the weathered cover and peels it back. She climbs up a ladder and hoists herself into the boat. Nick smiles at the strangeness of this, then climbs in after h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cabin, Kat flicks a couple of switches and a row o lights flicker on. She flicks another switch and a pierci sea-horn BLARES the “William Tell Overture.” She scramble to turn it off and checks the house for activity. A dog BARKS in the distance. Relieved, Kat pushes a tape into an old radio. MUSIC limp through hollow speakers. Kat leads Nick into the cabin and onto the bed. Without taking her eyes off him, Kat starts to slowly undress. He shirt drops to the floor. Then, a moment later, her skirt Kat breathes deeply then reaches behind her back and flic open her bra. We watch Kat’s face as she lets it fall to floor. Kat is indeed a woman who doesn’t do naked -- this killing her. On the bed, Nick doesn’t say anything, just watches. Kat wants to read something into his stare. Longing, desire, anything. But he’s utterly inscrutable. It’s both unnervi and extremely sexy. Kat steels herself and removes her underwear. She loses h nerve momentarily and pulls them up again. Finally, she slips them off and tries not to laugh as she scurries ont the bed. Hovering lazily in the waking dream of interrupted sleep Nick gazes at Kat. Ina trick of light, the cabin windows glow liquid, as though the moon were reflecting off water Nick runs his hand across Kat’s waist. She’s trying to ho back. He knows it and likes it. He takes her face in his hands and kisses her. It’s amazing. A different kind of kiss. They pull back and look at each other. In one swift movement, he flips Kat underneath him. Suddenly, the space between them collapses and they attac each other.  54.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat’s house beams in the scarlet light of dawn. Two BIN-M walk down the driveway toward the bins. They grab three b and drag them noisily past the boat parked in the drivewa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Kat and Nick, asleep, their faces pressed up aga each other. We PULL BACK to reveal Kat and Nick entwined, naked. We P BACK further to reveal that they’re covered with a fleece blanket and a pile of life vests. Nick opens his eyes and looks at Kat, who is as calm and content as we’ve seen her. Then, he realizes where he is. It’s like waking up in a strange hotel room, only weirder because it’s a boat...in a driveway...in London. Nick carefully extricates himself and begins to dress. We seen this scene a thousand times before, but Nick’s escap breathtakingly precise and practiced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick climbs down the ladder of the boat just as the Bin-M are returning the empty bins beside the garage. Nick give them a nod.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Morning. The guys nod back and finish their job as Nick sneaks tow the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor and Bunny sit at the kitchen table. Victor’s burie in the International Herald Tribune crossword puzzle. Bun looks out the window and sees Nick creeping towards the house, shoes in hand.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: She still thinks we don’t know about the boat thing. Victor looks up from his paper. He sees Nick, snorts, and goes back to his crossword.  55.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat’s eyes flutter open. Her hair is plastered into an impromptu quasi-beehive. She looks down at her “pillow.” It’s a buoy. Kat suddenly sits bolt upright. She grabs a life vest to cover her naked chest and looks around in horror. Then he eyes widen as she remembers the rest of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat slinks towards the house, retreading Nick’s walk of shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Victor looks up from his paper and sees Kat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat’s almost to the house when she hears a loud, POUNDING She looks up to see HER FATHER tapping on the window and laughing at her. Kat’s mortified, but can’t help smiling. She waves and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. KAT’S ROOM Kat looks around frantically for something. She finds her purse and checks to see if the ATM money is still there. is. She breathes a sigh of relief, then, hearing footstep hastily stuffs the wad back in. Nick opens the door, carrying a breakfast-in-bed tray. Ka spins around, guiltily.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure what works for you so I’ve got a pack of Saltines, a bottle of Pedialyte -- preferred by infants and rock stars -- an egg- and-cheese sandwich, a black coffee, and a Bloody Mary. Kat slumps onto the bed. She hasn’t gotten her land legs back yet.  56.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: This is really sweet of you, but I need to ask you something. (desperately) What happened last night? Nick is taken aback. He sets down the tray. He’s not sure what to say, then makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nothing. Kat looks surprised, then skeptical.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: We kissed. Made out a little. Then you passed out. She stares at him long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Whether it’s true or not, thank you. Kat disappears and Nick bites into a Saltine as the showe HISSES on. Then something catches his eye. It’s Kat’s pur lying next to the bed. Stuffed on top, A WAD OF MONEY. His brow furrows, Nick picks it up and le through the stack of pounds and euros. INT. KAT’S BATHROOM In the shower, Kat lets the scorching water punish and pu her.

dialogues.speaker: NICK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What’s this? Startled, Kat peeks her head out of the shower curtain an sees Nick holding the pile of money.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oh. Shoot. I-- She retreats into the shower, yanking the curtain closed.  57.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mouthing words) Shit! Shit! Shit! Nick pulls open the curtain and Kat instantly stops her pantomimed self-flagellation.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Is this for last night?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Of course not. How...how could it be? Nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: If I was going to charge you, I would have told you beforehand. I thought I explained that. Naked in front of Nick, Kat is trying not to flinch.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I didn’t want you to think I was expecting anything to be free or that I was expecting something at all. Well, clearly I was expecting something or I wouldn’t have stopped at all those ATMs on the way home. (beat) By the way, would it have been enough? I mean, if something had happened. Which it didn’t? Kat wants to slip down the drainpipe. Nick looks at her considers his words carefully.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Don’t they have a limit at those machines?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (quietly) Not if you take an advance on your credit card. Now Nick has to really try to stifle a laugh. Nick puts t money on the sink. He goes to leave, then turns back.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You’re three hundred short.  58. With that, he walks out. In the shower, Kat gently bangs head against the tile. She looks down and notices somethi

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: And my Brazilian wax looks like... Brazil. (resting against the tile) Awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nick and Victor are eating breakfast, the newspaper sprea out between them. Victor’s still working on the crossword puzzle.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: What’s a four letter word for daughter defiler? (beat, writing it in) Oh. N-I-C-K. Before Nick can react-- VICTOR (CONT’D) You a boating man, son? Victor’s expression is inscrutable. Nick weighs his optio and then--

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I am now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (laughing) At least somebody’s using the damn thing. (beat) I was gonna fix her up but we took one trip and the kids fought so much, we never launched her again. Just then, Kat walks in with an air of feigned nonchalanc

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: That’s not true. We checked for leaks a few years back (kisses her father) Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: Ahoy!  59. Kat throws him a look. He chuckles. As Nick gets up to ge himself some orange juice, Kat corners him behind the refrigerator door.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (hushed) So you’re telling me. If something had happened last night...it would have cost me fourteen hundred dollars? That’s a down payment on a Ford Focus!

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Not dollars. Pounds. Nick pours a glass of juice and offers it to Kat. Kat sha her head.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: My rate isn’t arbitrary. It was determined by prevailing market conditions. By the way, it includes oral. That’s the extra three hundred.... Pounds. He smiles and sips his juice. She is outraged by his presumption- -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: And what if I didn’t want you to...to do that to me?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: No, no. The three hundred is for you doing it to me.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Believe me, if anything had happened, that would have been one of the highlights. For you.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: But nothing did.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Yup. That’s why you get to keep your money. Nick walks away. Sits down next to Victor. Kat glares daggers at him. Nick smiles and toasts her with his juice  60. Just then, Amy enters in a flurry of cheerfulness, as if night never happened. Bunny follows, carrying a clipboard

dialogues.speaker: AMY
dialogues.text: Hey, Ginger! Hey, Gilligan! How much do I love all this? I’m going to get divorced and remarried over and over again so it’ll last forever. Kat, be a sweetie, and go help with the rings. No way Jeffrey’s going to get it right. Amy breezes out.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (to no one) I’d be happy to. You’re welcome.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t be that way.

dialogues.speaker: VICTOR
dialogues.text: (sticking up for Kat) Come on, Bun. Leave her alone.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: (to Kat) It’s not always about you, sweetie. Kat’s stung. Nick watches out of the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: How could you say that? Of course it’s not about me. It’s never about me when she’s in the room because you two are on a special team. You might as well have T- shirts made up. Kat lowers her voice.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I don’t know why I’m being so sensitive. I just get tired of being odd man out. Bunny looks over at Victor.

dialogues.speaker: BUNNY
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Bunny squeezes Kat’s cheek and kisses her.  61. BUNNY (CONT’D) Oh honey, it’s not that I love Amy more. It’s that she lets me love her. This flip comment hits Kat hard. BUNNY (CONT’D) (obliviously) I’m off. Ta-ta! As Bunny walks out, Victor raises an eyebrow, then goes b to his crossword. Kat stands a moment, feeling awkward.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (to Nick) Okay, then. I’11 catch up with you at the dance thing.... Sweetie. Nick gives Kat a casual nod. She exits. Behind the BUSINE section, Nick’s face is a mask. Then he smiles. This girl is nuts. A door BUZZES. INT. JEWELRY STORE - ST. JOHN’S WOOD Kat enters and approaches SAL, 60, a tough-talking, Cockn teddy bear.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Hey, Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: I heard you were back in town kitty cat. You’re here for the highland flings, I bet.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I get all the glamour jobs. He smiles and heads into the back. Kat casually looks int the counter. Her face is blank as she scans row after row engagement rings. Sal reemerges with two ring boxes. Kat takes the rings an smiles.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks, Sally. She turns to go.  62.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: The one I made for you is the cherries. You hang onto it or give it back?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Give it back? Are you nuts?

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: You pawned it.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
